text: Someday I’ll be grown up enough to have a designated guest room with clean sheets and towels all ready to go, but today is not that day. [Shoveling papers on desk into a pile and sweating as I make the daybed with trundle in the office and semi-dusting]
author: laura11D

author: laura11D

text: Just had a neighbor knock on my door to tell me that her twins were going to get held back from kindergarten and she was so upset. We talked for an hour, until I remembered that I was late for a work webinar. I love working from home, because I'm here for those conversations.
author: laura11D

author: laura11D

text: A friend who graduated from Brooklyn tech in the 80s told me that the school had greater numbers of black and Latino kids back then. She said her middle school test prepped all the honors kids for a full year for that qualifying exam. But also thinks the city has changed.
author: laura11D

text: Arthur Ave, Bronx https://www.instagram.com/p/BvPbWpVHNh2/?utm_source=ig_twitter_share&igshid=1f7e36x6offz9 …
author: laura11D

text: When the path to an elite urban school is too complicated, kids w/savvy parents have a huge edge. @elizashapiro's article shows how that pans out. By all accounts, school reform in Newark simplified and streamlined the path towards elite schools. It can be done.
author: laura11D

text: IXL for reading and Kumon for math for my kid with autism. HUGE benefits for him. Out of spec ed for math now. Maybe honors next year. And up two reading levels.
author: laura11D

text: Jonah’s home for spring break, so we’re going to read The Prince together for his theory class. Much better than a booze filled week in Florida, am I right? #bestparentever
author: laura11D

text: Are Beto and Amy O'Rourke the future of politics or the past?
author: laura11D

text: Yeah, but they aren't protesting adjunct pay. That's just fine with them. 70 percent of Rutgers faculty are adjuncts. https://www.njspotlight.com/stories/18/04/12/beyond-signs-and-slogans-what-does-rutgers-adjunct-faculty-want/ …
author: laura11D

text: Come from the Olivia Jade gossip and the mad vocal fry, but stay for the discussion of the stress and craziness and awful girl culture in elite high schools in LA. https://mol.im/a/6824803  via @MailOnline
author: laura11D

text: SpongeBob! She's got my vote for life!
author: laura11D

text: We love it, too. And good beer.
author: laura11D

text: #showershamed
author: laura11D

text: Simply changing the exam isn't going to achieve equality. There are too many other hurdles. The right answer is that there shouldn't be two tiers of schools in NYC. Every school should be awesome.
author: laura11D

text: Those schools aren't in the neighborhood, so they require a parent with a flexible schedule to get the kid to the school. That rules out another huge group of kids. It ruled out us, because I couldn't bear to wake up a napping baby to get Jonah downtown.
author: laura11D

text: The gifted and talented high schools need an IQ test. The pre-school gave us the names of the right shrinks who would give us the right numbers. It cost money. So, that immediately rules out about half the city kids.
author: laura11D

text: so we prepped for Jonah for a NYC kindergarten. They have a very complicated system of choice in the city. Our nothing-fancy YMCA pre-school gave presentations to the parents on how to handle the paperwork and information.
author: laura11D

text: When Jonah was four, we lived in a seriously awful apartment in Wash Heights.  I carried two babies up a five floor walk up, had no laundry in the building, and sometimes had no heat in the dead of winter. For a year, we weren't sure if we were going to stay in the hood or move..
author: laura11D

text: None of this is new. These tech-heavy schools in NYC benefit the Asian-American community, and the other gifted and talented high schools in the city benefit the white middle class. It's a way to keep them in the city, so they don't move to the burbs.
author: laura11D

text: Just because I work from home, it doesn't mean that I'm using my spare minutes to productively disinfect my bathroom. So, I finally broke down and hired a cleaning lady. She's making judge-y comments in a heavy Polish accent about my shower stall at this moment.
author: laura11D

text: I mean what is Hunger Games other than the fight for college admissions, really?
author: laura11D

text: About five years ago, I wrote an essay than I never ended up publishing anywhere talking about how the rise in dystopian YA novels was a sign that kids were really f*cked up today. My theory was that teens preferred fictional dystopias to their realities.
author: laura11D

text: Between 2011 and 2015, there was a 28 percent increase in psychiatric emergency department (ED) visits among young people ages 6 to 2. Visits spiked 54 percent for teens, 53 percent for African-American youth, and 91 percent for young Hispanic patients.
author: laura11D

text: Imagine the cops coming to your door saying that arrested a criminal who was breaking into your shed. Yay. Aren’t you happy? And, oh by the way, the cops say, what are all those unopened boxes of televisions doing in your shed?

text: What I find so funny about all this is that the Feds say that the victims of the crime were elite universities. But the elite universities are not happy about this. They didn't want this kind of attention.
author: laura11D

text: The lawyers for these parents are going to claim that Singer tricked them. They didn't want to cheat, but Singer told them that everyone did it. Parents were deceived and duped.
author: laura11D

text: America has become more and more unequal, affluent parents have become increasingly desperate to pass on their privileges to their children and avoid downward mobility at all costs. https://www.chronicle.com/article/What-the-Admissions-Scandal/245901/#.XI0OHQWxcbl.twitter … via @chronicle
